title: 114_hr2770
content: The Act is titled the "Keeping our Travelers Safe and Secure Act". The "Keeping our Travelers Safe and Secure Act" emphasizes the importance of maintaining security-related technology for the Transportation Security Administration's mission to protect US transportation systems. Preventive and corrective maintenance are crucial for extending the service lives of this technology, as highlighted by the Inspector General's audit in May 2015. The Inspector General found that the Transportation Security Administration's lack of proper maintenance management for security-related technology at airports could lead to equipment not being ready for operational use, potentially requiring less effective screening measures. The Transportation Security Administration's lack of maintenance management for security technology at airports could lead to less effective screening measures, potentially jeopardizing passenger safety and security. SEC. 3. MAINTENANCE OF SECURITY-RELATED TECHNOLOGY. Amends the Homeland Security Act to include a new section on Maintenance Validation and Oversight for security-related technology. The Administrator must develop a preventive maintenance validation process for security-related technology at airports within 180 days of the enactment of this subtitle. The process includes guidance for Administration personnel and contractors on conducting and documenting maintenance actions, as well as mechanisms for verifying compliance. Maintenance by Administration personnel and contractors at airports is outlined in the process. The Administrator must ensure that maintenance contracts for security-related technology at airports include monthly preventive maintenance schedules, notification of completed maintenance actions, and independent validation by a third party. Penalties for noncompliance with maintenance requirements must be included in the contracts. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include new specifications related to security technology maintenance at airports. The Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security will assess the implementation of security technology maintenance requirements within one year of the Act's enactment. Findings and recommendations will be provided regarding training for personnel and the availability of equipment maintenance technicians.
